description: The "synthetic.skills" table represents a collection of unique skills, each identified by a primary key "skill_id." It includes details such as the skill's name, category, and description, along with timestamps for when each entry was created and last updated. This table operates independently, with no foreign key relationships, serving as a standalone repository of skill-related information within the synthetic_250_postgres database.

columns.name: skill_id
columns.description: This column represents a unique identifier for each skill entry in the database. Each skill is assigned a distinct consecutive integer to ensure its identification within the system.

columns.name: skill_name
columns.description: This column represents textual descriptions or reflections of skills or competencies, potentially related to personal development, professional experience, or job roles. Purpose unclear from available data.

columns.name: category
columns.description: This column seems to categorize different themes or topics, potentially related to various activities, professions, or areas of focus. The purpose is unclear from the available data, as the samples are phrases lacking consistent or specific semantic patterns.

columns.name: description
columns.description: This column contains narratives or brief descriptive sentences that outline experiences, activities, or observations related to skill sets, likely used to provide context or examples of skill application. The purpose is unclear from available data.

columns.name: created_at
columns.description: This column records the date and time when a skill entry was created in the system. Purpose unclear from available data.

columns.name: updated_at
columns.description: This column records the date and time when a skills record was last modified. It helps track changes made to the information over time.

indexes.index_definition: CREATE UNIQUE INDEX skills_pkey ON synthetic.skills USING btree (skill_id)
CREATE UNIQUE INDEX skills_skill_name_key ON synthetic.skills USING btree (skill_name)
